page.title: 15CORNISH HEDGEROWS
page.content: A typical Cornish Hedge is built mostly of local stone, wider at the base than at the top with an infill of earth through the middle.The top course of stones, called'copestones' or 'Jack and Jill', is often placed vertically to permit drainage. On top of the hedge, turf cut from the immediate area is placed. Colonisation of bushes in a Cornish hedge is slow because of its structure and the exposed nature of the countryside.But grasses and wild flowers thrive in the shelter provided and are able to grow in and on the hedge because of the soil used in its construction. The lack of shrubs, bushes and trees does limit this environment compared to some 'up-country' hedgerows which are entirely constructed of plants. {LIST OF PLANTS ON NEXT PAGE}
